newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey backs Iraq no-fly zone despite France row.
newsitem.headline: Turkey backs Iraq no-fly zone despite France row.

text.p: The Turkish parliament on Wednesday backed further U.S.-led air patrols to monitor a no-fly zone in northern Iraq despite doubts over French committment to the flights.

Deputy speaker Kamer Genc said MPs voted 255 to 217 to give Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's government the power to authorise the allied use of Incirlik air base in southern Turkey for air probes into northern Iraq,
The draft accepted by parliament did not mention any French participation in the flights, intended to shield Iraq's Kurds from any attack by Baghdad.
Talks in Turkey on the future of the patrols hit a snag earlier in the day when France raised objections on technical details, Turkish officials said.
The U.S., French and British air force's mandate runs out on December 31.
The allies have been flying over northern Iraq to ward off Iraqi governemnt aircraft since shortly after the Gulf War in 1991.
But the force's ground element in northern Iraq was scrapped after President Saddam Hussein gained a foothold in the region in inter-Kurdish fighting in late August.
Under pressure from Turkey's military, Islamist Erbakan has gone back on previous promises to throw the planes out of Turkey.
